trans-unit.source: Process events from Event Hubs with Storm on HDInsight | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Process events from Event Hubs with Storm on HDInsight | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to process Event Hubs data with a C# Storm topology created in Visual Studio using the HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to process Event Hubs data with a C# Storm topology created in Visual Studio using the HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Azure Event Hubs allows you to process massive amounts of data from websites, apps, and devices.
trans-unit.target: Azure Event Hubs allows you to process massive amounts of data from websites, apps, and devices.

trans-unit.source: The Event Hubs spout makes it easy to use Apache Storm on HDInsight to analyze this data in real time.
trans-unit.target: The Event Hubs spout makes it easy to use Apache Storm on HDInsight to analyze this data in real time.

trans-unit.source: You can also write data to Event Hubs from Storm by using the Event Hubs bolt.
trans-unit.target: You can also write data to Event Hubs from Storm by using the Event Hubs bolt.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will learn how to use the HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio and the Event Hubs spout and bolt to create two hybrid C#/Java topologies:
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will learn how to use the HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio and the Event Hubs spout and bolt to create two hybrid C#/Java topologies:

trans-unit.source: EventHubWriter: Randomly generates data and writes it to Event Hubs
trans-unit.target: EventHubWriter: Randomly generates data and writes it to Event Hubs

trans-unit.source: EventHubReader: Reads data from Event Hubs and stores it in Azure Table storage
trans-unit.target: EventHubReader: Reads data from Event Hubs and stores it in Azure Table storage

trans-unit.source: An Apache Storm on HDInsight cluster
trans-unit.target: An Apache Storm on HDInsight cluster

trans-unit.source: An Azure Event Hub
trans-unit.target: An Azure Event Hub

trans-unit.source: The Azure .NET SDK
trans-unit.target: The Azure .NET SDK

trans-unit.source: The HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio (the 2/17/2015 version or later)
trans-unit.target: The HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio (the 2/17/2015 version or later)

trans-unit.source: You can download a complete version of the project created in this tutorial from GitHub: <linkText>eventhub-storm-hybrid</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You can download a complete version of the project created in this tutorial from GitHub: <linkText>eventhub-storm-hybrid</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: However, you still need to provide configuration settings by following the steps in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: However, you still need to provide configuration settings by following the steps in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: When you use the completed project, you must use the NuGet Package Manager to restore the packages that are required by this solution.
trans-unit.target: When you use the completed project, you must use the NuGet Package Manager to restore the packages that are required by this solution.

trans-unit.source: The Event Hubs spout and bolt are Java components that allow you to easily work with Event Hubs from Apache Storm.
trans-unit.target: The Event Hubs spout and bolt are Java components that allow you to easily work with Event Hubs from Apache Storm.

trans-unit.source: Although these components are written in Java, the HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio allow you to create hybrid topologies that mix C# and Java components.
trans-unit.target: Although these components are written in Java, the HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio allow you to create hybrid topologies that mix C# and Java components.

trans-unit.source: The spout and bolt are distributed as a single Java archive (.jar) file named eventhubs-storm-spout-0.9-jar-with-dependencies.jar.
trans-unit.target: The spout and bolt are distributed as a single Java archive (.jar) file named eventhubs-storm-spout-0.9-jar-with-dependencies.jar.

trans-unit.source: The most recent version of the eventhubs-storm-spout-0.9-jar-with-dependencies.jar file is included in the HDInsight Storm examples project under the lib folder.
trans-unit.target: The most recent version of the eventhubs-storm-spout-0.9-jar-with-dependencies.jar file is included in the HDInsight Storm examples project under the lib folder.

trans-unit.source: To download the file, use one of the following methods.
trans-unit.target: To download the file, use one of the following methods.

trans-unit.source: The spout and bolt have been submitted for inclusion in the Apache Storm project.
trans-unit.target: The spout and bolt have been submitted for inclusion in the Apache Storm project.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see STORM-583: Initial check-in for storm-event hubs in GitHub.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see STORM-583: Initial check-in for storm-event hubs in GitHub.

trans-unit.source: Download a ZIP file: From the HDInsight Storm examples site, select Download ZIP in the right pane to download a .zip file that contains the project.
trans-unit.target: Download a ZIP file: From the HDInsight Storm examples site, select Download ZIP in the right pane to download a .zip file that contains the project.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>download zip button</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>download zip button</linkText>

trans-unit.source: After the file is downloaded, you can extract the archive, and the file will be in the lib directory.
trans-unit.target: After the file is downloaded, you can extract the archive, and the file will be in the lib directory.

trans-unit.source: Clone the project: If you have Git installed, use the following command to clone the repository locally, then find the file in the lib directory.
trans-unit.target: Clone the project: If you have Git installed, use the following command to clone the repository locally, then find the file in the lib directory.

trans-unit.source: Event Hubs is the data source for this example.
trans-unit.target: Event Hubs is the data source for this example.

trans-unit.source: Use the following steps to create a new Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: Use the following steps to create a new Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure portal, select NEW > Service Bus > Event Hub > Custom Create.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure portal, select NEW > Service Bus > Event Hub > Custom Create.

trans-unit.source: On the Add a new Event Hub screen, enter an Event Hub Name, select the Region to create the hub in, and create a new namespace or select an existing one.
trans-unit.target: On the Add a new Event Hub screen, enter an Event Hub Name, select the Region to create the hub in, and create a new namespace or select an existing one.

trans-unit.source: Click the Arrow to continue.
trans-unit.target: Click the Arrow to continue.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>wizard page 1</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>wizard page 1</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You should select the same Location as your Storm on HDInsight server to reduce latency and costs.
trans-unit.target: You should select the same Location as your Storm on HDInsight server to reduce latency and costs.

trans-unit.source: On the Configure Event Hub screen, enter the Partition count and Message Retention values.
trans-unit.target: On the Configure Event Hub screen, enter the Partition count and Message Retention values.

trans-unit.source: For this example, use a partition count of 10 and a message retention of 1.
trans-unit.target: For this example, use a partition count of 10 and a message retention of 1.

trans-unit.source: Note the partition count because you will need this value later.
trans-unit.target: Note the partition count because you will need this value later.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>wizard page 2</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>wizard page 2</linkText>

trans-unit.source: After the event hub has been created, select the namespace, select Event Hubs, and then select the event hub that you created earlier.
trans-unit.target: After the event hub has been created, select the namespace, select Event Hubs, and then select the event hub that you created earlier.

trans-unit.source: Select Configure, then create two new access policies by using the following information.
trans-unit.target: Select Configure, then create two new access policies by using the following information.

trans-unit.source: Name
trans-unit.target: Name

trans-unit.source: Permissions
trans-unit.target: Permissions

trans-unit.source: Writer
trans-unit.target: Writer

trans-unit.source: Send
trans-unit.target: Send

trans-unit.source: Reader
trans-unit.target: Reader

trans-unit.source: Listen
trans-unit.target: Listen

trans-unit.source: After You create the permissions, select the Save icon at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: After You create the permissions, select the Save icon at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: This creates the shared access policies that will be used to send (writer) and listen (reader) to this Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: This creates the shared access policies that will be used to send (writer) and listen (reader) to this Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>policies</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>policies</linkText>

trans-unit.source: After you save the policies, use the Shared access key generator at the bottom of the page to retrieve the key for the writer and reader policies.
trans-unit.target: After you save the policies, use the Shared access key generator at the bottom of the page to retrieve the key for the writer and reader policies.

trans-unit.source: Save these because they will be used later.
trans-unit.target: Save these because they will be used later.

trans-unit.source: Table storage will be used to hold the values that are read from Event Hubs because you can easily view Table storage from inside Visual Studio through Server Explorer.
trans-unit.target: Table storage will be used to hold the values that are read from Event Hubs because you can easily view Table storage from inside Visual Studio through Server Explorer.

trans-unit.source: Use the following steps to create new Table storage:
trans-unit.target: Use the following steps to create new Table storage:

trans-unit.source: From the Azure portal, select NEW > Data Services > Storage > Quick Create.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure portal, select NEW > Data Services > Storage > Quick Create.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>quick create storage</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>quick create storage</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Enter a Name for the storage account, select a Location, and then click the check mark to create the storage account.
trans-unit.target: Enter a Name for the storage account, select a Location, and then click the check mark to create the storage account.

trans-unit.source: You should select the same Location as your Event Hubs and Storm on HDInsight server to reduce latency and costs.
trans-unit.target: You should select the same Location as your Event Hubs and Storm on HDInsight server to reduce latency and costs.

trans-unit.source: When the new storage account is provisioned, select the account and then use the Manage Access Keys link at the bottom of the page to retrieve the Storage Account Name and Primary Access Key.
trans-unit.target: When the new storage account is provisioned, select the account and then use the Manage Access Keys link at the bottom of the page to retrieve the Storage Account Name and Primary Access Key.

trans-unit.source: Save this information because it will be used later.
trans-unit.target: Save this information because it will be used later.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>access keys</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>access keys</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will create a topology that writes data to Event Hubs by using the Event Hubs bolt.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will create a topology that writes data to Event Hubs by using the Event Hubs bolt.

trans-unit.source: If you have not already installed the latest version of the HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio, see Get started using HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: If you have not already installed the latest version of the HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio, see Get started using HDInsight Tools for Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Open Visual Studio, select File > New and then Project.
trans-unit.target: Open Visual Studio, select File > New and then Project.

trans-unit.source: From the New Project screen, expand Installed > Templates, and select HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: From the New Project screen, expand Installed > Templates, and select HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: From the list of templates, select Storm Application.
trans-unit.target: From the list of templates, select Storm Application.

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the screen, enter EventHubWriter as the name of the application.
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the screen, enter EventHubWriter as the name of the application.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>image</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>image</linkText>

trans-unit.source: After the project is created, you should have the following files:
trans-unit.target: After the project is created, you should have the following files:

trans-unit.source: Program.cs: This defines the topology for your project.
trans-unit.target: Program.cs: This defines the topology for your project.

trans-unit.source: Note that a default topology that consists of one spout and one bolt is created by default.
trans-unit.target: Note that a default topology that consists of one spout and one bolt is created by default.

trans-unit.source: Spout.cs: An example spout.
trans-unit.target: Spout.cs: An example spout.

trans-unit.source: Bolt.cs: An example bolt.
trans-unit.target: Bolt.cs: An example bolt.

trans-unit.source: This will be deleted because you will use the Event Hubs bolt to write to Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: This will be deleted because you will use the Event Hubs bolt to write to Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click EventHubWriter, and then select Properties.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click EventHubWriter, and then select Properties.

trans-unit.source: In the project properties, select Settings, and then select **This project does not contain a default settings file.
trans-unit.target: In the project properties, select Settings, and then select **This project does not contain a default settings file.

trans-unit.source: Click here to create one.**
trans-unit.target: Click here to create one.**

trans-unit.source: Enter the following settings.
trans-unit.target: Enter the following settings.

trans-unit.source: Use the information for the Event Hub you created earlier in the Value column.
trans-unit.target: Use the information for the Event Hub you created earlier in the Value column.

trans-unit.source: Name
trans-unit.target: Name

trans-unit.source: Type
trans-unit.target: Type

trans-unit.source: Scope
trans-unit.target: Scope

trans-unit.source: EventHubPolicyName
trans-unit.target: EventHubPolicyName

trans-unit.source: string
trans-unit.target: string

trans-unit.source: Application
trans-unit.target: Application

trans-unit.source: EventHubPolicyKey
trans-unit.target: EventHubPolicyKey

trans-unit.source: string
trans-unit.target: string

trans-unit.source: Application
trans-unit.target: Application

trans-unit.source: EventHubNamespace
trans-unit.target: EventHubNamespace

trans-unit.source: string
trans-unit.target: string

trans-unit.source: Application
trans-unit.target: Application

trans-unit.source: EventHubName
trans-unit.target: EventHubName

trans-unit.source: string
trans-unit.target: string

trans-unit.source: Application
trans-unit.target: Application

trans-unit.source: EventHubPartitionCount
trans-unit.target: EventHubPartitionCount

trans-unit.source: int
trans-unit.target: int

trans-unit.source: Application
trans-unit.target: Application

trans-unit.source: Save and close the Properties page.
trans-unit.target: Save and close the Properties page.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click Bolt.cs, and select Delete.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click Bolt.cs, and select Delete.

trans-unit.source: You are using the Java Event Hubs bolt, so you do not need this file.
trans-unit.target: You are using the Java Event Hubs bolt, so you do not need this file.

trans-unit.source: Open the Program.cs file and add the following code immediately after the TopologyBuilder topologyBuilder = new TopologyBuilder("EventHubWriter"); line.
trans-unit.target: Open the Program.cs file and add the following code immediately after the TopologyBuilder topologyBuilder = new TopologyBuilder("EventHubWriter"); line.

trans-unit.source: The first line reads the partition count from the properties defined earlier.
trans-unit.target: The first line reads the partition count from the properties defined earlier.

trans-unit.source: The second line defines a deserializer that is used to deseralize JSON data produced by the spout, into a java.lang.String so that Java components can consume the data.
trans-unit.target: The second line defines a deserializer that is used to deseralize JSON data produced by the spout, into a java.lang.String so that Java components can consume the data.

trans-unit.target: Find the following code:

trans-unit.target: Replace it with the following:

trans-unit.source: This creates a spout and uses the Event Hubs partition count as the parallelism hint for this component.
trans-unit.target: This creates a spout and uses the Event Hubs partition count as the parallelism hint for this component.

trans-unit.source: This should create an instance of the spout for each partition.
trans-unit.target: This should create an instance of the spout for each partition.

trans-unit.source: This also associates the deserializer created previously with the output stream from this component.
trans-unit.target: This also associates the deserializer created previously with the output stream from this component.

trans-unit.source: This allows the downstream EventHubSpout component to consume the data produced from the C# spout.
trans-unit.target: This allows the downstream EventHubSpout component to consume the data produced from the C# spout.

trans-unit.source: Immediately after the previous code, add the following:
trans-unit.target: Immediately after the previous code, add the following:

trans-unit.source: This creates a new constructor for the Java bolt, which is used at run time to configure a new instance of the bolt.
trans-unit.target: This creates a new constructor for the Java bolt, which is used at run time to configure a new instance of the bolt.

trans-unit.source: In this case, you are using the Apache Storm Clojure DSL to configure the spout with the Event Hubs configuration information you added previously.
trans-unit.target: In this case, you are using the Apache Storm Clojure DSL to configure the spout with the Event Hubs configuration information you added previously.

trans-unit.source: More specifically, this code is used by HDInsight at run time to do the following:
trans-unit.target: More specifically, this code is used by HDInsight at run time to do the following:

trans-unit.source: Create a new instance of com.microsoft.eventhubs.bolt.EventHubBoltConfig using the Event Hubs information you provide.
trans-unit.target: Create a new instance of com.microsoft.eventhubs.bolt.EventHubBoltConfig using the Event Hubs information you provide.

trans-unit.source: Create a new instance of com.microsoft.eventhubs.bolt.EventHubBolt, passing in the EventHubBoltConfig instance.
trans-unit.target: Create a new instance of com.microsoft.eventhubs.bolt.EventHubBolt, passing in the EventHubBoltConfig instance.

trans-unit.source: Find the following code:
trans-unit.target: Find the following code:

trans-unit.target: Replace it with the following:

trans-unit.source: This instructs the topology to use the JavaComponentConstructor from the previous step as the bolt.
trans-unit.target: This instructs the topology to use the JavaComponentConstructor from the previous step as the bolt.

trans-unit.source: The component can be referred to in this topology by the friendly name of "EventHubBolt."
trans-unit.target: The component can be referred to in this topology by the friendly name of "EventHubBolt."

trans-unit.source: The parallelism hint is set to the number of partitions for the Event Hub, and it subscribes to data produced by the spout ("Spout").
trans-unit.target: The parallelism hint is set to the number of partitions for the Event Hub, and it subscribes to data produced by the spout ("Spout").

trans-unit.source: At this point, you are done with the Program.cs.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you are done with the Program.cs.

trans-unit.source: The topology has been defined, but now you must modify Spout.cs so that it produces data in a format that the Event Hubs bolt can use.
trans-unit.target: The topology has been defined, but now you must modify Spout.cs so that it produces data in a format that the Event Hubs bolt can use.

trans-unit.source: This topology will default to creating one worker process, which is sufficient for example purposes.
trans-unit.target: This topology will default to creating one worker process, which is sufficient for example purposes.

trans-unit.source: If you are adapting this for a production cluster, you should can add the following to change the number of workers:
trans-unit.target: If you are adapting this for a production cluster, you should can add the following to change the number of workers:

trans-unit.source: The Event Hubs bolt expects a single string value, which it will route to Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: The Event Hubs bolt expects a single string value, which it will route to Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: In the following example, you will modify the default Spout.cs file to produce a JSON string.
trans-unit.target: In the following example, you will modify the default Spout.cs file to produce a JSON string.

trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, open Spout.cs and add the following at the top of the file:

trans-unit.target: The JSON.NET package should already be installed, as it is required by the SCP.NET framework used for C# Storm topologies.

trans-unit.target: Save the Spout.cs file.

trans-unit.source: At this point, you have a basic topology that will generate random data and store it in Event Hubs by using the Event Hubs bolt.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you have a basic topology that will generate random data and store it in Event Hubs by using the Event Hubs bolt.

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will create a topology that reads data from Event Hubs by using the Event Hubs spout.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will create a topology that reads data from Event Hubs by using the Event Hubs spout.

trans-unit.source: Open Visual Studio, select File > New > Project.
trans-unit.target: Open Visual Studio, select File > New > Project.

trans-unit.source: From the New Project screen, expand Installed > Templates, and select HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: From the New Project screen, expand Installed > Templates, and select HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: From the list of templates, select Storm Application.
trans-unit.target: From the list of templates, select Storm Application.

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the screen, enter EventHubReader as the name of the application.
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the screen, enter EventHubReader as the name of the application.

trans-unit.source: For TableName, enter the name of the table that you want events to be stored in.
trans-unit.target: For TableName, enter the name of the table that you want events to be stored in.

trans-unit.source: For StorageConnection, enter a value of DefaultEndpointsProtocol=https;AccountName=myAccount;AccountKey=myKey;.
trans-unit.target: For StorageConnection, enter a value of DefaultEndpointsProtocol=https;AccountName=myAccount;AccountKey=myKey;.

trans-unit.source: Replace myAccount and myKey with the storage account name and key obtained earlier.
trans-unit.target: Replace myAccount and myKey with the storage account name and key obtained earlier.

trans-unit.source: These values will be used by the topology to communicate with Event Hubs and Table Storage.
trans-unit.target: These values will be used by the topology to communicate with Event Hubs and Table Storage.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click Spout.cs and select Delete.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click Spout.cs and select Delete.

trans-unit.source: You are using the Java Event Hubs spout, so you do not need this file.
trans-unit.target: You are using the Java Event Hubs spout, so you do not need this file.

trans-unit.source: Open the Program.cs file and add the following code immediately after the TopologyBuilder topologyBuilder = new TopologyBuilder("EventHubReader"); line:
trans-unit.target: Open the Program.cs file and add the following code immediately after the TopologyBuilder topologyBuilder = new TopologyBuilder("EventHubReader"); line:

trans-unit.source: The partition count is read and assigned to a local variable.
trans-unit.target: The partition count is read and assigned to a local variable.

trans-unit.source: It will be used multiple times.
trans-unit.target: It will be used multiple times.

trans-unit.source: The EventHubSpoutConfig defines the configuration for the Event Hub spout.
trans-unit.target: The EventHubSpoutConfig defines the configuration for the Event Hub spout.

trans-unit.source: In this case, the Event Hubs configuration information you added previously.
trans-unit.target: In this case, the Event Hubs configuration information you added previously.

trans-unit.source: Behind the scenes this uses the Java Event Hub spout, and will create a new instance of com.microsoft.eventhubs.spout.EventHubSpoutConfig using the Event Hubs information.
trans-unit.target: Behind the scenes this uses the Java Event Hub spout, and will create a new instance of com.microsoft.eventhubs.spout.EventHubSpoutConfig using the Event Hubs information.

trans-unit.source: Find the following code:
trans-unit.target: Find the following code:

trans-unit.source: Replace it with the following:
trans-unit.target: Replace it with the following:

trans-unit.source: This instructs the topology to create a new Event Hub spout and use the EventHubSpoutConfig from the previous step as the configuration.
trans-unit.target: This instructs the topology to create a new Event Hub spout and use the EventHubSpoutConfig from the previous step as the configuration.

trans-unit.source: "EventHubSpout" sets the friendly name of the spout, and partitionCount is used to set the parallelism hint.
trans-unit.target: "EventHubSpout" sets the friendly name of the spout, and partitionCount is used to set the parallelism hint.

trans-unit.source: Behind the scenes this creates a new instance of com.microsoft.eventhubs.spout.EventHubSpout Java component using the provided configuration information.
trans-unit.target: Behind the scenes this creates a new instance of com.microsoft.eventhubs.spout.EventHubSpout Java component using the provided configuration information.

trans-unit.target: Add the following immediately after the previous code:

trans-unit.source: This creates a custom serializer, which will be used to serialize information produced by the Java components (such as the EventHubSpout) into a JSON format that downstream C# components can use.
trans-unit.target: This creates a custom serializer, which will be used to serialize information produced by the Java components (such as the EventHubSpout) into a JSON format that downstream C# components can use.

trans-unit.source: Find the following code:
trans-unit.target: Find the following code:

trans-unit.source: Replace it with the following:
trans-unit.target: Replace it with the following:

trans-unit.source: This code instructs the topology to use a bolt (defined in Bolt.cs).
trans-unit.target: This code instructs the topology to use a bolt (defined in Bolt.cs).

trans-unit.source: The custom serializer defined earlier is used here so that this bolt can consume data produced by upstream Java components.
trans-unit.target: The custom serializer defined earlier is used here so that this bolt can consume data produced by upstream Java components.

trans-unit.source: In this case, the EventHubSpout.
trans-unit.target: In this case, the EventHubSpout.

trans-unit.source: The last parameter for SetBolt, (with a value of true,) enables ACK functionality for this bolt.
trans-unit.target: The last parameter for SetBolt, (with a value of true,) enables ACK functionality for this bolt.

trans-unit.source: This is required, as the EventHubSpout component expects an ACK for data that it emits.
trans-unit.target: This is required, as the EventHubSpout component expects an ACK for data that it emits.

trans-unit.source: If ACKs are not returned by downstream components, the spout will stop receiving after processing around 1000 messages.
trans-unit.target: If ACKs are not returned by downstream components, the spout will stop receiving after processing around 1000 messages.

trans-unit.source: At this point, you are done with Program.cs.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you are done with Program.cs.

trans-unit.source: The topology has been defined, but now you must create a helper class to write data to Table storage, then you must modify Bolt.cs so that it can understand the data produced by the spout.
trans-unit.target: The topology has been defined, but now you must create a helper class to write data to Table storage, then you must modify Bolt.cs so that it can understand the data produced by the spout.

trans-unit.source: This topology will default to creating one worker process, which is sufficient for example purposes.
trans-unit.target: This topology will default to creating one worker process, which is sufficient for example purposes.

trans-unit.source: If you are adapting this for a production cluster, you should can add the following to change the number of workers:
trans-unit.target: If you are adapting this for a production cluster, you should can add the following to change the number of workers:

trans-unit.source: When writing data to Table storage, you must create a class that describes the data that will be written.
trans-unit.target: When writing data to Table storage, you must create a class that describes the data that will be written.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the EventHubReader project, and select Add, then New Class.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the EventHubReader project, and select Add, then New Class.

trans-unit.source: Name the new class Devices.cs.
trans-unit.target: Name the new class Devices.cs.

trans-unit.source: Open Devices.cs and replace the default code with the following:
trans-unit.target: Open Devices.cs and replace the default code with the following:

trans-unit.source: This creates entities in Table storage that consist of a partition key (which will be set to the device ID read from Event Hub,) a unique row key, and a value that is read from Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: This creates entities in Table storage that consist of a partition key (which will be set to the device ID read from Event Hub,) a unique row key, and a value that is read from Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: Each entity will also have a timestamp, which will be created automatically when the entity is inserted in the table.
trans-unit.target: Each entity will also have a timestamp, which will be created automatically when the entity is inserted in the table.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, expand the EventHubReader project and open the Bolt.cs file.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, expand the EventHubReader project and open the Bolt.cs file.

trans-unit.source: Add the following at the top of the file:
trans-unit.target: Add the following at the top of the file:

trans-unit.source: This allows you to more easily work with JSON data from the bolt and write data to Table storage.
trans-unit.target: This allows you to more easily work with JSON data from the bolt and write data to Table storage.

trans-unit.source: Find the private int count; statement and replace it with the following:
trans-unit.target: Find the private int count; statement and replace it with the following:

trans-unit.source: This will be used when connecting to the table.
trans-unit.target: This will be used when connecting to the table.

trans-unit.source: Find the following code:
trans-unit.target: Find the following code:

trans-unit.target: Replace it with the following:

trans-unit.source: This instructs the bolt that it will be receiving a string value instead of an int, and that the data should be deserialized using the CustomizedInteropJSONDeserialzer that was declared in the topology earlier (in the program.cs file).
trans-unit.target: This instructs the bolt that it will be receiving a string value instead of an int, and that the data should be deserialized using the CustomizedInteropJSONDeserialzer that was declared in the topology earlier (in the program.cs file).

trans-unit.source: Immediately after the previous code, add the following:
trans-unit.target: Immediately after the previous code, add the following:

trans-unit.source: This connects to the events table by using the connection string configured previously.
trans-unit.target: This connects to the events table by using the connection string configured previously.

trans-unit.source: If it does not exist, it will be created.
trans-unit.target: If it does not exist, it will be created.

trans-unit.source: Find the Execute method and replace it with the following:
trans-unit.target: Find the Execute method and replace it with the following:

trans-unit.source: This uses Json.NET to parse the JSON data from the spout, and then picks out the deviceId and deviceValue fields.
trans-unit.target: This uses Json.NET to parse the JSON data from the spout, and then picks out the deviceId and deviceValue fields.

trans-unit.source: A new Device object is then created by using the deviceId during initialization to set the partition key for the table.
trans-unit.target: A new Device object is then created by using the deviceId during initialization to set the partition key for the table.

trans-unit.source: The value is then set to the deviceValue, and finally the entity is inserted into the table.
trans-unit.target: The value is then set to the deviceValue, and finally the entity is inserted into the table.

trans-unit.source: After the entity is inserted into the table, Ack() is called for the tuple, to inform the spout that we have successfully processed the data.
trans-unit.target: After the entity is inserted into the table, Ack() is called for the tuple, to inform the spout that we have successfully processed the data.

trans-unit.source: The EventHubSpout component expects an ACK for each tuple from downstream components such as this bolt.
trans-unit.target: The EventHubSpout component expects an ACK for each tuple from downstream components such as this bolt.

trans-unit.source: If ACKS are not received, the EventHubSpout will assume processing for the tuple has failed.
trans-unit.target: If ACKS are not received, the EventHubSpout will assume processing for the tuple has failed.

trans-unit.source: At this point, you have a complete topology that will read data from Event Hub, and store it in Table Storage in a table named events.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you have a complete topology that will read data from Event Hub, and store it in Table Storage in a table named events.

trans-unit.source: From Solution Explorer, right-click the EventHubReader project and select Submit to Storm on HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: From Solution Explorer, right-click the EventHubReader project and select Submit to Storm on HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>submit to storm</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>submit to storm</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the Submit Topology screen, select your Storm Cluster.
trans-unit.target: On the Submit Topology screen, select your Storm Cluster.

trans-unit.source: Expand Additional Configurations, select Java File Paths, select ... and select the directory that contains the eventhubs-storm-spout-0.9-jar-with-dependencies.jar file that you downloaded earlier.
trans-unit.target: Expand Additional Configurations, select Java File Paths, select ... and select the directory that contains the eventhubs-storm-spout-0.9-jar-with-dependencies.jar file that you downloaded earlier.

trans-unit.source: Finally, click Submit.
trans-unit.target: Finally, click Submit.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Image of submission dialog</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Image of submission dialog</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When the topology has been submitted, the Storm Topologies Viewer will appear.
trans-unit.target: When the topology has been submitted, the Storm Topologies Viewer will appear.

trans-unit.source: Select the EventHubReader topology in the left pane to view statistics for the topology.
trans-unit.target: Select the EventHubReader topology in the left pane to view statistics for the topology.

trans-unit.source: Currently, nothing should be happening because no events have been written to Event Hubs yet.
trans-unit.target: Currently, nothing should be happening because no events have been written to Event Hubs yet.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>example storage view</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>example storage view</linkText>

trans-unit.source: From Solution Explorer, right-click the EventHubWriter project and select Submit to Storm on HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: From Solution Explorer, right-click the EventHubWriter project and select Submit to Storm on HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: On the Submit Topology screen, select your Storm Cluster.
trans-unit.target: On the Submit Topology screen, select your Storm Cluster.

trans-unit.source: Expand Additional Configurations, select Java File Paths, select ... and select the directory that contains the eventhubs-storm-spout-0.9-jar-with-dependencies.jar file you downloaded earlier.
trans-unit.target: Expand Additional Configurations, select Java File Paths, select ... and select the directory that contains the eventhubs-storm-spout-0.9-jar-with-dependencies.jar file you downloaded earlier.

trans-unit.source: Finally, click Submit.
trans-unit.target: Finally, click Submit.

trans-unit.source: When the topology has been submitted, refresh the topology list in the Storm Topologies Viewer to verify that both topologies are running on the cluster.
trans-unit.target: When the topology has been submitted, refresh the topology list in the Storm Topologies Viewer to verify that both topologies are running on the cluster.

trans-unit.source: When both topologies are running, select Server Explorer, then expand Azure > Storage, and select the Storage Account you created earlier.
trans-unit.target: When both topologies are running, select Server Explorer, then expand Azure > Storage, and select the Storage Account you created earlier.

trans-unit.source: Under the Storage Account, expand Tables.
trans-unit.target: Under the Storage Account, expand Tables.

trans-unit.source: Finally, double-click the events table to open the table.
trans-unit.target: Finally, double-click the events table to open the table.

trans-unit.source: You should see data that has been stored in the table from the EventHubReader topology.
trans-unit.target: You should see data that has been stored in the table from the EventHubReader topology.

trans-unit.source: The events are being generated by the EventHubWriter topology, which writes them to Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: The events are being generated by the EventHubWriter topology, which writes them to Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: The EventHubReader then reads the events from Event Hubs and stores them in Table storage in the events table.
trans-unit.target: The EventHubReader then reads the events from Event Hubs and stores them in Table storage in the events table.

trans-unit.source: To stop the topologies, select each topology in the Storm Topology Viewer, then click Kill.
trans-unit.target: To stop the topologies, select each topology in the Storm Topology Viewer, then click Kill.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>image of killing a topology</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>image of killing a topology</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The EventHubSpout periodically checkpoints its state to the Zookeeper node, which saves the current offset for messages read from the queue.
trans-unit.target: The EventHubSpout periodically checkpoints its state to the Zookeeper node, which saves the current offset for messages read from the queue.

trans-unit.source: This allows the component to start receiving messages at the saved offset in the following scenarios:
trans-unit.target: This allows the component to start receiving messages at the saved offset in the following scenarios:

trans-unit.source: The component instance fails and is restarted.
trans-unit.target: The component instance fails and is restarted.

trans-unit.source: You grow or shrink the cluster by adding or removing nodes.
trans-unit.target: You grow or shrink the cluster by adding or removing nodes.

trans-unit.source: The topology is killed and restarted with the same name.
trans-unit.target: The topology is killed and restarted with the same name.

trans-unit.source: You can also export and import the persisted checkpoints to WASB (the Azure Storage used by your HDInsight cluster.)
trans-unit.target: You can also export and import the persisted checkpoints to WASB (the Azure Storage used by your HDInsight cluster.)

trans-unit.source: The scripts to do this are located on the Storm on HDInsight cluster, at c:\apps\dist\storm-0.9.3.2.2.1.0-2340\zkdatatool-1.0\bin.
trans-unit.target: The scripts to do this are located on the Storm on HDInsight cluster, at c:\apps\dist\storm-0.9.3.2.2.1.0-2340\zkdatatool-1.0\bin.

trans-unit.source: The version number in the path may be different, as the version of Storm installed on the cluster may change in the future.
trans-unit.target: The version number in the path may be different, as the version of Storm installed on the cluster may change in the future.

trans-unit.source: The scripts in this directory are:
trans-unit.target: The scripts in this directory are:

trans-unit.source: stormmeta_import.cmd: Import all Storm metadata from the cluster default storage container into Zookeeper.
trans-unit.target: stormmeta_import.cmd: Import all Storm metadata from the cluster default storage container into Zookeeper.

trans-unit.source: stormmeta_export.cmd: Export all Storm metadata from Zookeeper to the cluster default storage container.
trans-unit.target: stormmeta_export.cmd: Export all Storm metadata from Zookeeper to the cluster default storage container.

trans-unit.source: stormmeta_delete.cmd: Delete all Storm metadata from Zookeeper.
trans-unit.target: stormmeta_delete.cmd: Delete all Storm metadata from Zookeeper.

trans-unit.source: Export an import allows you to persist checkpoint data when you need to delete the cluster, but want to resume processing from the current offset in the hub when you bring a new cluster back online.
trans-unit.target: Export an import allows you to persist checkpoint data when you need to delete the cluster, but want to resume processing from the current offset in the hub when you bring a new cluster back online.

trans-unit.source: Since the data is persisted to the default storage container, the new cluster must use the same storage account and container as the previous cluster.
trans-unit.target: Since the data is persisted to the default storage container, the new cluster must use the same storage account and container as the previous cluster.

trans-unit.source: In this document, you have learned how to use the Java Event Hubs Spout and Bolt from a C# topology to work with data in Azure Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: In this document, you have learned how to use the Java Event Hubs Spout and Bolt from a C# topology to work with data in Azure Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about creating C# topologies, see the following.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about creating C# topologies, see the following.

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Develop C# topologies for Apache Storm on HDInsight using Visual Studio</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Example topologies for Storm on HDInsight</linkText><title></title>
